title: Transitional serif text font used in 'The Palmer Method of Business Writing' (1935)
content:
I quite like the crisp rationality of the text typeface used in this book, but I can't identify it. I suspect it's a Linotype machine face, judging by the buttonhook 'f' and the overly wide italic.

[http://www.iampeth.com/books/palmer\_method\_1935/palmerMethod\_1935\_page2....](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317180234/http:/www.iampeth.com/books/palmer_method_1935/palmerMethod_1935_page2.html "http://www.iampeth.com/books/palmer\_method\_1935/palmerMethod\_1935\_page2.html")

I particularly like the 'g', which strikes me as rather distinctive.

Font: 

 Century Old Style (probably) 

Solved By: 

 [fvilanakis](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317180234/http:/typophile.com/user/176276 "View user profile.")
author: altsan

comments.content:
@fvilanakis Thanks. It does look like it, doesn't it?

The book type seems rather less condensed than the digital Century Old Style fonts I see. (Letters like 'o' look noticeably rounder, and the tracking in general is much looser.) But I supposed that could be accounted for by a different size being used for the digital masters.

Yes, it looks very close and I can't spot a similar /g on any other font I looked.  
You can find a more "round" (less compressed) version of Century Old Style on the latin subset of (Chinese) Mac OS font **[Biau Kai](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317180234/http:/www.findmyfont.com/index.php/fonts/font-preview?fset=Mac-OS-Fonts&ffam=BiauKai%20-%20Regular&fid=9ff1c78eed95d3ffed256f524b2a7b78&fsize=48&text=EXPLANATION%20good%2C%20practical%20business%20writers&wrap=2)** (1995) but I doubt the book is set on Biau Kai  
See also:  
 [http://typophile.com/node/76885](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317180234/http:/typophile.com/node/76885 "http://typophile.com/node/76885")
